docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Are we Windows System Tools? Windows Security Tools? Windows Server Tools? Yes and no. WSTools are all those things and more. Whatever you decide you want to call WSTools is up to you! However, officially, we are Wandering Stag Tools (WSTools). WSTools was written for System Administrators, Help Desk Technicians, and other Network Operations personnel to automate tasks and provide valuable tools. As of 2023 there are over 300 functions in this module. Some functionality includes:

  • Active Directory functions, reports, and shortcuts allowing for easier domain management and awareness
  • Computer/Server Management
  • Install/uninstall software
  • Remediation tasks such as disabling vulnerable SCHANNEL settings
  • Set network and system settings
  • Reports
  • PowerShell snippets in PowerShell ISE and VS Code for easier coding
  • Conversions such as image files to base64, int64 to/from IP, uint16 to string

docs.title: Issues
docs.text: Please Open an issue if there are any problems or requests. Opening an issue does require having a GitHub account.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
1. PowerShell: version 2 for most functions but some individual functions require version 3 or version 5. Some plans have been made to add some functions that require version 7. Check your version of PowerShell by entering the following command: $host Then look at the Version attribute.
  2. Active Directory PowerShell module: Not needed for everything but is necessary for 30+ functions.
  3. NetIQ DRA PowerShell REST Extensions: Not needed for many functions at the moment but there are plans to add more.
  4. Local Admin Password Solution (LAPS): Actual module name: AdmPwd.PS. There are a handful of functions that require the full install of LAPS to get the module and not just the basic install. However, if you are not using LAPS on your network then there are no worries.
  5. Microsoft.Exchange.Management.PowerShell.Admin PSSnapin: Required for the very few Exchange server related functions.

docs.title: Download
docs.text: Intended only for Windows computers at this time. Some functions may work on other OS's though.

docs.title: From GitHub
docs.text:
1. Click on the Green Code button with the down arrow.
  2. Select Download ZIP.
  3. Change the name of the file from WSTools-master.zip to WSTools.zip.

docs.title: Install
docs.text:
1. Uncompress the WSTools.zip file.
  2. Make available globally or just for single user.

docs.title: Global
docs.text:
Copy the WSTools folder to C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules

Requires admin rights.

docs.title: User only
docs.text:
Copy the WSTools folder to C:\Users\\\Documents\WindowsPowerShell\Modules

If the folder already exists or you get a message saying "The destination has # files with the same names." you can either delete the folder that already exists (prefered) or you can Replace the files in the destination

docs.title: Initial changes to make after copying to computer
docs.text:
General Configuration

  1. Open PowerShell (after WSTools has been added to one of the locations above)
  2. Type Set-WSToolsConfig and then press Enter. In the file that opens you will need to update the values so they work on your network. > Recommend copying this file (config.ps1) to another location after you modify it so if you download a newer version of WSTools you can just paste the config file back unless there are changes in the config file.

Remote installation of .msu files and a select few other things:

  1. Open WSTools Module Path then edit InstallRemote.ps1 > Typically C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules\WSTools or C:\Users\<USERNAME>\Documents\WindowsPowerShell\Modules\WSTools
  2. On Line 1 of InstallRemote.ps1 change the value of $PatchFolderPath to the directory on remote computers you store windows updates. This is predefined as "C:\Patches".

docs.title: Visual Studio Code setup
docs.text:
For adding the Visual Studio Code PowerShell Snippets do the following:

  1. Open PowerShell (after WSTools has been added to one of the locations above)
  2. Type the following command: Set-PowerShellJSON

or

  1. Open the WSTools folder > Typically C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules\WSTools or C:\Users\<USERNAME>\Documents\WindowsPowerShell\Modules\WSTools).
  2. Cut and paste powershell.json to %AppData%\Roaming\Code\User\Snippets directory.

or

  1. Open powershell.json (located in the WSTools module folder) and copy the text then in VSCode Command Palette (Ctrl + Shift + P)
  2. Type Snippet and select Preferences: Configure User Snippets.
  3. Type PowerShell then press Enter.
  4. Select powershell.json.
  5. Paste the copied text between the { } brackets and save the file.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: This module contains over 300 different functions used for day to day tasks and once in a blue moon tasks. With more being written all the time. It is an accumulation of thousands of hours of research, development, testing, and real world use by multiple organizations. It covers domain management (Active Directory – Windows domains), Insider Threat, remediation/patch management, PowerShell automation, and several other areas.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Clears dirty shutdown registry key.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Clear-DirtyShutdown [[-ComputerName] <String[]>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Clears the registry key that prompts you to enter a reason the computer/server was shutdown, even after a clean shutdown.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Clear-DirtyShutdown

Will clear a dirty shutdown that causes the shutdown tracker to appear.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Clear-DirtyShutdown -ComputerName COMP1

Will clear the dirty shutdown on COMP1. You must have admin rights on the remote computer.

Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Clears Application Data folder that was improperly copied which happens when copy and pasting a profile.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Clear-ImproperProfileCopy [-Source] <String> [-Destination] <String> [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Copies nested Application Data folders to a higher level (by default to C:\f2) and deletes them.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Clear-ImproperProfileCopy -Source \\fileserver\example\user -Destination E:\f2

Clears nested Application Data folders from \\fileserver\example\user. Uses E:\f2 as the folder for clearing.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Clear-ImproperProfileCopy E:\temp\Profile E:\f2

Clears nested Application Data folders from E:\temp\Profile. Uses E:\f2 as the folder for clearing.

docs.title: -Destination
docs.text:
Specifies the folder that is used to copy the nested folders to and deletes them.

Type: String
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: True
Position: 2
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -Source
docs.text:
Specifies the folder that contains the Application Data folder causing issues.

Type: String
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: True
Position: 1
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Clears the C:\Patches folder.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text:
Clear-Patches [-ObjectList] <String[]> [-Recursive] [-Old] [[-MaxThreads] <Int32>] [[-SleepTimer] <Object>]
 [[-MaxResultTime] <Object>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Removes items in the C:\Patches folder on the local or remote computer.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Clear-Patches

Clears C:\Patches folder on the local computer (but not the inidividual program folders.)

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Clear-Patches -ComputerName COMP1

Clears C:\Patches folder on the computer COMP1.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 3
docs.text:
Clear-Patches -ComputerName (gc c:\complist.txt) -Recursive

Clears all files and folders in C:\Patches on the computers listed in the file c:\complist.txt.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 4
docs.text:
Clear-Patches -ComputerName (gc c:\complist.txt) -Old

Clears files in the root of C:\Patches that are older than 28 days on the computers listed in the file c:\complist.txt.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Clears harddrive space

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Clear-Space [[-ComputerName] <String[]>] [-InvokeMethod] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Clears harddrive space by clearing temp files and caches. Invoke method does not clear as many locations.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Clear-Space

Clears temp and cache data on the local computer

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Clear-Space -ComputerName COMP1

Clears temp and cache data on the computer COMP1

docs.title: EXAMPLE 3
docs.text:
Clear-Space -ComputerName (gc c:\complist.txt)

Clears temp and cache data on the computers listed in the file c:\complist.txt

docs.title: EXAMPLE 4
docs.text:
Clear-Space -ComputerName (gc c:\complist.txt) -InvokeMethod

Clears temp and cache data on the computers listed in the file c:\complist.txt using the Invoke-WMIMethod command.

docs.title: -ComputerName
docs.text:
Specifies the computer or computers to clear space on

Type: String[]
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases: Host, Name, Computer, CN

Required: False
Position: 1
Default value: "$env:COMPUTERNAME"
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -InvokeMethod
docs.text:
Specifies the computer or computers to clear space on using the Invoke-WMIMethod command #DevSkim: ignore DS104456

Type: SwitchParameter
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: Named
Default value: False
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Converts uin16 arrays to a readable string.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Convert-Uint16ToString [[-Members] <UInt16[]>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Take the members from a uint16 array and converts it to a user friendly string.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Convert-Uint16ToString $uint16array

Converts the uint16 array in the $uint16array variable.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Convert-Uint16ToString ((Get-CimInstance WmiMonitorID -Namespace root/WMI)[0] | Select-Object -ExpandProperty SerialNumberID)

Converts the SerialNumberID of the first monitor to a readable format.

docs.title: -Members
docs.text:
Takes the array members for a uint16 array.

Type: UInt16[]
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 1
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Enables PowerShell Snippets in Visual Studio Code.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Copy-PowerShellJSON [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Copies the powershell.json file from the WSTools module folder to %AppData%\Roaming\Code\User\snippets for the currently logged on user.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Copy-PowerShellJSON

Copies the powershell.json file from the WSTools module folder to %AppData%\Roaming\Code\User\snippets for the currently logged on user.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Copies the UpdateHistory.csv report to the UHPath config item path.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Copy-UpdateHistory [[-ComputerName] <String[]>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Copies the UpdateHistory.csv report created with Save-UpdateHistory to the UHPath config item path for the local computer or remote computers.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Copy-UpdateHistory

Example of how to use this cmdlet to copy the UpdateHistory.csv file for the local computer to the UHPath location.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Copy-UpdateHistory -ComputerName Server1

Example of how to use this cmdlet to copy the UpdateHistory.csv file for the remote computer Server1 to the UHPath location.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: This function exports a users mailbox to a pst.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Export-MessagesToPST [-TargetUserAlias] <String> [[-ExportPath] <String>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: This function exports a users mailbox to a pst.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Export-MessagesToPST -TargetUserAlias joe.snuffy

Exports joe.snuffy's mailbox to C:\Users\Desktop\joe.snuffy_mailboxyyyyMMddhhmm.pst where yyyyMMddhhmm is the date and time the mailbox was exported.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Export-MessagesToPST -TargetUserAlias joe.snuffy -ExportPath "c:\test"

Exports joe.snuffy's mailbox to C:\test\joe.snuffy_mailboxyyyyMMddhhmm.pst where yyyyMMddhhmm is the date and time the mailbox was exported.

docs.title: -ExportPath
docs.text:
By default saves to the logged on users desktop. You can specify where to save the pst to.

Type: String
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 2
Default value: ([System.Environment]::GetFolderPath("Desktop"))
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -TargetUserAlias
docs.text:
Mandatory parameter. Specify the users alias in Exchange or primary smtp address.

Type: String
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: True
Position: 1
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: This function will show empty groups.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Find-EmptyGroup [[-SearchBase] <String>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: This function will show empty groups in your domain.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Find-EmptyGroups -SearchBase "OU=test,dc=yourdomain,dc=com"

This function searches the test OU under the yourdomain.com domain and saves a csv with empty groups to c:\test\emptygroups.csv.

docs.title: -SearchBase
docs.text:
Specific OU to search. If not included, the entire domain will be searched.

Type: String
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 1
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Checks attributes on Active Directory objects against a set of compliance rules.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text:
Get-ADComplianceReport [[-UserSearchBase] <String[]>] [[-UserGroupSearchBase] <String[]>]
 [[-AdminSearchBase] <String[]>] [[-AdminGroupSearchBase] <String[]>] [[-ComputerSearchBase] <String[]>]
 [[-MSASearchBase] <String[]>] [[-OrganizationalSearchBase] <String[]>] [[-ServerSearchBase] <String[]>]
 [[-ServiceAccountSearchBase] <String[]>] [-SaveADReports] [[-ReportFolder] <String>] [-SaveReport]
 [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Checks attributes on Active Directory objects against a set of compliance rules and provides a report. It also takes several attributes and makes them human readable.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Get-ADComplianceReport

Example of how to use this cmdlet. Will default to OUs in config file.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Get-ADComplianceReport -UserSearchBase 'OU=Example User OU,DC=wstools,DC=dev'

Will search the 'OU=Example User OU,DC=wstools,DC=dev' OU for user objects and report on them.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 3
docs.text:
Get-ADComplianceReport -UserSearchBase 'OU=Example User OU,DC=wstools,DC=dev' -SaveReport

Will search the 'OU=Example User OU,DC=wstools,DC=dev' OU for user objects and because the -ReportFolder parameter is not used to specify a path, it will save the report to C:\Scripts.

docs.title: -AdminGroupSearchBase
docs.text:
Specify the distinguishedName(s) of organizational units (OUs) to search for group objects that have admins.

Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Position: 4
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: True (ByPropertyName)
Accept wildcard characters: False

Accept wildcard characters: False

Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.text:
Specify where you want to save reports to. If you do not specify a path and use either the SaveADReports or SaveReport switches this defaults to C:\Scripts.

Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 10
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -SaveADReports
docs.text:
Will save data pulled from Active Directory to reports for each object matching their type to path in ReportFolder parameter.

Type: SwitchParameter
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -SaveReport
docs.text:
Will save the report in csv format. If a path isn't specified using the ReportFolder parameter it will save to C:\Scripts.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Get-FileMetaData [[-Path] <String[]>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: This function gets file metadata using the Shell.Application object and returns a custom PSObject object that can be sorted, filtered or otherwise manipulated.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Get-FileMetaData -Path "e:\music"

Gets file metadata for all files in the e:\music directory

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Get-FileMetaData -Path (gci e:\music -Recurse -Directory).FullName

This example uses the Get-ChildItem cmdlet to do a recursive lookup of all directories in the e:\music folder and then it goes through and gets all of the file metada for all the files in the directories and in the subdirectories.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 3
docs.text:
Get-FileMetaData -Path "c:\fso","E:\music\Big Boi"

Gets file metadata from files in both the c:\fso directory and the e:\music\big boi directory.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 4
docs.text:
$meta = Get-FileMetaData -Path "E:\music"

This example gets file metadata from all files in the root of the e:\music directory and stores the returned custom objects in a $meta variable for later processing and manipulation.

docs.title: -Path
docs.text:
The path that is parsed for files

Type: String[]
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 1
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Gets the Http Header setting on the current machine.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Get-HttpHeaderSetting [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Displays the name and value of Http Header settings on the local computer. Blank entries means the value is not created.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Get-HttpHeaderSetting

Example of how to use this cmdlet. Will show Http Header settings on the computer. Will output something similar to this: Name Disabled FullPath ---- -------- -------- Parameters 1 HKLM:\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\HTTP\Parameters

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Lists IPs within a range, subnet, or CIDR block.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text:
Get-IPrange [[-IP] <String>] [-CIDR <String>] [-Subnet <String>] [-Start <String>] [-End <String>]
 [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Lists IPs within a range, subnet, or CIDR block.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Get-IPrange -ip 192.168.0.3 -subnet 255.255.255.192

Will show all IPs within the 192.168.0.0 space with a subnet mask of 255.255.255.192 (CIDR 26.)

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Get-IPrange -PARAMETER

Another example of how to use this cmdlet but with a parameter or switch.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Displays installed programs on a computer.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text:
Get-InstalledProgram [[-ComputerName] <String[]>] [[-Property] <String[]>] [-WhatIf] [-Confirm]
 [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Displays a list of installed programs on a local or remote computer by querying the registry.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Get-InstalledProgram

Shows the installed programs on the local computer.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Get-InstalledProgram -ComputerName COMPUTER1

Shows the installed programs on the remote computer COMPUTER1.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 3
docs.text:
Get-InstalledProgram -ComputerName COMPUTER1,COMPUTER2

Shows the installed programs on the remote computers COMPUTER1 and COMPUTER2.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 4
docs.text:
Get-InstalledProgram (gc C:\Temp\computers.txt)

Shows the installed programs on the remote computers listed in the computers.txt file (each computer name on a new line.)

docs.title: EXAMPLE 5
docs.text:
Get-InstalledProgram COMPUTER1 -Property InstallSource

Shows the installed programs on the remote computer COMPUTER1 and also shows the additional property InstallSource from the registry.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 6
docs.text:
Get-InstalledProgram COMPUTER1,COMPUTER2 -Property InstallSource,Comments

Shows the installed programs on the remote computers COMPUTER1 and COMPUTER2. Also shows the additional properties InstallSource and Comments from the registry.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: This function will locate the computer that processed a failed user logon attempt which caused the user account to become locked out.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Get-LockedOutLocation [-Identity] <String> [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: This function will locate the computer that processed a failed user logon attempt which caused the user account to become locked out. The locked out location is found by querying the PDC Emulator for locked out events (4740). The function will display the BadPasswordTime attribute on all of the domain controllers to add in further troubleshooting.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Get-LockedOutLocation -Identity Joe.Davis

This example will find the locked out location for Joe Davis.

{{ Fill Identity Description }}

Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: NOTES
docs.text: This function is only compatible with an environment where the domain controller with the PDCe role to be running Windows Server 2008 SP2 and up. The script is also dependent the ActiveDirectory PowerShell module, which requires the AD Web services to be running on at least one domain controller. Author:Jason Walker Last Modified: 3/20/2013

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Gets Operating System information

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Get-OperatingSystem [[-ComputerName] <String[]>] [-Registry] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Gets Operating System information via WMI query (Default) or Registry query (Switch.) Determines whether the computer is 32-bit or 64-bit, the Operating System name, and the OS Build number.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Get-OperatingSystem

Gets Operating System information for the local computer

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Get-OperatingSystem -Registry

Gets Operating System information for the local computer via Registry query instead os WMI query

docs.title: EXAMPLE 3
docs.text:
Get-OperatingSystem -ComputerName SERVER1

Gets Operating System information for computer SERVER1

docs.title: EXAMPLE 4
docs.text:
Get-OperatingSystem -ComputerName (gc c:\complist.txt) -Registry

Gets Operating System information for all computers listed in c:\complist.txt via Registry queries

docs.title: -ComputerName
docs.text:
Specify computer or computer names to query

Type: String[]
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases: Host, Name, Computer, CN

Required: False
Position: 1
Default value: "$env:COMPUTERNAME"
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -Registry
docs.text:
Use Registry queries instead of WMI queries

Type: SwitchParameter
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 2
Default value: False
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.text: AUTHOR: Skyler Hart CREATED: 06/06/2015 20:11:37 LASTEDIT: 2021-11-26 17:02:59 KEYWORDS: Operating System, OS REMARKS: For local computer it can be ran as user. For remote computers, it needs to be ran as a user who has administrative rights on the remote computer.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Gets the SCHANNEL settings on the current machine.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Get-SCHANNELSetting [[-Name] <String>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Displays the name and value of SCHANNEL settings on the local computer. Blank entries means the value is not created.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Get-SCHANNELSetting

Example of how to use this cmdlet. Will show all SCHANNEL settings on the computer. Will output something similar to this: Name DisabledByDefault Enabled FullPath ---- ----------------- ------- -------- Ciphers\DES 56/56 0 HKLM:\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurityPro... Ciphers\NULL 0 HKLM:\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurityPro.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Get-SCHANNELSetting -Name Ciphers

Will show all the Ciphers configured in the SCHANNEL registry settings.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 3
docs.text:
Get-SCHANNELSetting -Name "TLS 1.0"

Will show all the TLS 1.0 SCHANNEL registry settings configured on the computer.

docs.title: -Name
docs.text:
Used to specify the name of a SCHANNEL setting to display. Uses matching.

Type: String
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases: Path

Required: False
Position: 1
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Shows USB storage devices that have connected to a computer.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Get-USBStorageDevice [[-ComputerName] <String[]>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Shows USB storage devices that have connected to a local or remote computer. Limitations apply. Only shows devices that are listed in the registry. Sometimes, depending on the computer that is only the most recent device.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Get-USBStorageDevice

Example of how to use this cmdlet on a local computer.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Get-USBStorageDevice -ComputerName COMP1

Shows the USB storage devices that have connected to the remote computer COMP1.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Will install patches in the local patches folder.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Install-Patches [[-ComputerName] <String[]>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Installes patches in the LocalPatches config setting path (default is C:\Patches.)

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Install-Patches

Will install patches in the LocalPatches config setting path (default is C:\Patches.)

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Install-Patches -ComputerName COMP1,COMP2

Will install patches in the LocalPatches config setting path (default is C:\Patches) on COMP1 and COMP2.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Will install VMware tools on one or more computers.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Install-VMwareTools [[-ComputerName] <String[]>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Installes VMware Tools from the C:\Patches\VMware directory. Uses config file to determine network path to copy to the local computer first. On remote computers, install file will need to already exist (use Copy-VMwareTools).

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Install-VMwareTools

Will install VMware Tools from setup file in C:\Patches\VMwareTools.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Install-VMwareTools -ComputerName COMP1,COMP2

Will install VMware Tools from setup file in C:\Patches\VMwareTools on COMP1 and COMP2.

docs.title: -ComputerName
docs.text:
Specifies the name of one or more computers to install VMware Tools on.

Type: String[]
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases: Host, Name, Computer, CN

Required: False
Position: 1
Default value: "$env:COMPUTERNAME"
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Installs/copies the WSTools PowerShell module to a remote computer.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text:
Install-WSTools [[-ComputerName] <String[]>] [[-MaxThreads] <Int32>] [[-SleepTimer] <Object>]
 [[-MaxResultTime] <Object>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Copies the WSTools module from the location specified in the WSTools config file (config.ps1) for UpdatePath to the C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules\WSTools folder on the remote computer.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Install-WSTools COMPNAME

How to install the WSTools PowerShell module on the remote computer COMPNAME.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Install-WSTools -ComputerName COMPNAME1,COMPNAME2

How to install the WSTools PowerShell module on the remote computers COMPNAME1 and COMPNAME2.

docs.title: NOTES
docs.text: AUTHOR: Skyler Hart CREATED: Sometime before 2017-08-07 LASTEDIT: 2020-09-28 09:25:48 KEYWORDS: REQUIRES: -RunAsAdministrator on remote computers

docs.title: RELATED LINKS
docs.text:
[https://wanderingstag.github.io

-- CAS.log Provides information about the process of downloading software updates to the local cache and cache management.

CIAgent.log Provides information about processing configuration items, including software updates.

LocationServices.log Provides information about the location of the WSUS server when a scan is initiated on the client.

PatchDownloader.log Provides information about the process for downloading software updates from the update source to the download destination on the site server.

Note On 64-bit operating systems and on 32-bit operating systems without Configuration Manager 2007 installed, PatchDownloader.log is created in the server logs directory. On 32-bit operating systems, if the Configuration Manager 2007 client is installed, and on the synchronization host computer for the Inventory Tool for Microsoft Updates, PatchDownloader.log is created in the client logs directory.

PolicyAgent.log Provides information about the process for downloading, compiling, and deleting policies on client computers.

PolicyEvaluator Provides information about the process for evaluating policies on client computers, including policies from software updates.

RebootCoordinator.log Provides information about the process for coordinating system restarts on client computers after software update installations.

ScanAgent.log Provides information about the scan requests for software updates, what tool is requested for the scan, the WSUS location, and so on.

ScanWrapper Provides information about the prerequisite checks and the scan process initialization for the Inventory Tool for Microsoft Updates on Systems Management Server (SMS) 2003 clients.

SdmAgent.log Provides information about the process for verifying and decompressing packages that contain configuration item information for software updates.

ServiceWindowManager.log Provides information about the process for evaluating configured maintenance windows.

smscliUI.log Provides information about the Configuration Manager Control Panel user interactions, such as initiating an Software Updates Scan Cycle from the Configuration Manager Properties dialog box, opening the Program Download Monitor, and so on.

SmsWusHandler Provides information about the scan process for the Inventory Tool for Microsoft Updates on SMS 2003 client computers.

StateMessage.log Provides information about when software updates state messages are created and sent to the management point.

UpdatesDeployment.log Provides information about the deployment on the client, including software update activation, evaluation, and enforcement. Verbose logging shows additional information about the interaction with the client user interface.

UpdatesHandler.log Provides information about software update compliance scanning, and the download and installation of software updates on the client.

UpdatesStore.log Provides information about the compliance status for the software updates that were assessed during the compliance scan cycle.

WUAHandler.log Provides information about when the Windows Update Agent on the client searches for software updates.

WUSSyncXML.log Provides information about the Inventory Tool for Microsoft Updates synchronization process. This log is only on the client computer configured as the synchronization host for the Inventory Tool for Microsoft Updates. --]()

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Removes SusClientID registry key on the local or remote computer.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Repair-DuplicateSusClientID [[-ComputerName] <String[]>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: When creating a computer from a template (virtual disc) the SusClientID isn't changed and will result in WSUS only having one object for all the computers created. This function clears the SusClientID from the registry on the local or remote computer(s) so when syncing with WSUS a new SusClientID will be created. The first initial sync with WSUS typically fails. It may take several minutes for the computer to sync appropriately with WSUS.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Repair-DuplicateSusClientID

Example of how to use this cmdlet to fix a duplicate SusClientID on the local computer.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Repair-DuplicateSusClientID -ComputerName Server1

Another example of how to use this cmdlet but with the ComputerName parameter. In this example, Server1 is a remote computer.

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Enables SMB v1.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Set-SMBv1Fix [[-ComputerName] <String[]>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Turns SMBv1 on. While this fix action turns SMBv1 on, group policy can turn SMBv1 off, which is counted on.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Set-SMBv1Fix COMP1

Sets the fix action on COMP1. After the fix action is applied, COMP1 will need to be rebooted.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Set-SMBv1Fix

Sets the fix action on the local computer. After the fix action is applied, the local computer will need to be rebooted.

docs.title: -ComputerName
docs.text:
Specifies the computer or computers

Type: String[]
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases: Host, Name, Computer, CN

Required: False
Position: 1
Default value: "$env:COMPUTERNAME"
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Takes a single command and multithreads it.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text:
Start-CommandMultiThreaded [[-Command] <String>] [[-Objects] <String[]>] [[-MaxThreads] <Int32>]
 [[-MaxTime] <Int32>] [[-SleepTimer] <Int32>] [[-AddParameter] <Hashtable>] [[-AddSwitch] <Array>]
 [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Will multithread any command/cmdlet/function you specify.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Start-CommandMultiThreaded Clear-Space (gc c:\Scripts\comps.txt)

Will run the Clear-Space command against nine of the computers in the comps.txt file at a time. This is because the -MaxThreads parameter isn't set so it runs at the default of 9 objects at a time.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
gc c:\Scripts\comps.txt | Start-CommandMultiThreaded Clear-Space

Will run the Clear-Space command against nine of the computers in the comps.txt file at a time. This is because the -MaxThreads parameter isn't set so it runs at the default of 9 objects at a time.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 3
docs.text:
Start-CommandMultiThreaded -Command Get-Service -Objects (gc c:\Scripts\comps.txt) -AddParameter @{"Name" = "wuauserv"} -AddSwitch @('RequiredServices','DependentServices')

Will get the service "wuauserv" and it's dependent/required services from the computers listed in comps.txt.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 4
docs.text:
Start-CommandMultiThreaded -Command Set-AxwayConfig -Objects COMP1,COMP2 -AddParameter @{"ConfigFile" = "C:\PKI\MyOrgsAxwayConfig.txt"}

Will set the Axway config file on both the computer COMP1 and COMP2 at the same time using C:\PKI\MyOrgsAxwayConfig.txt on those computers as the file to import.

docs.title: -AddParameter
docs.text:
Allows specifying additional parameters beyond what is used in Objects. Need to format in a hash table. Ex: @{"ParameterName" = "Value"} or @{"ParameterName" = "Value";"AnotherParameter" = "AnotherValue"}

Type: Hashtable
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 6
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -AddSwitch
docs.text:
Allows specifying additional switches to add to the command you run. Need to format in a single string or an array of strings. Ex: "TotalCount" or @("TotalCount","All")

Type: Array
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 7
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -Command
docs.text:
Where you specify the command you want to multithread.

Type: String
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 1
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -MaxThreads
docs.text:
The maximum threads to run. Can cause resource issues.

Type: Int32
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 3
Default value: 9
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -MaxTime
docs.text:
The amount of seconds to run the script after last job (object) is started.

Type: Int32
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 4
Default value: 300
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -Objects
docs.text:
The arguments that are provided to the command. Generally used for specifying the name of one or more computers. However, it can be used for specifying other arguments such as a list of users.

Type: String[]
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 2
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: True (ByPropertyName, ByValue)
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -SleepTimer
docs.text:
The amount of milliseconds between each time the script checks the status of jobs. For high resource utilization on the system or if the script is going to take longer to run, this should be increased.

Type: Int32
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 5
Default value: 500
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Finds the MTU size for packets to a remote computer.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Test-MTU [[-RemoteAddress] <String[]>] [[-BufferSizeMax] <Int32>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Will find the point where packets don't fragment (MTU) to a remote source, which defaults to the computers logon server if an address isn't specified.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Test-MTU

Example of how to use this cmdlet.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Test-MTU www.wanderingstag.com

Shows how to test the MTU to the website www.wanderingstag.com.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 3
docs.text:
Test-MTU COMP1,www.wanderingstag.com

Shows how to test the MTU to the computer COMP1 and the website www.wanderingstag.com.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 4
docs.text:
Test-MTU COMP1 1272

Shows how to test the MTU to the computer COMP1, the max buffer size (MTU) will start at 1272.

docs.title: -BufferSizeMax
docs.text:
Allows you to specify the highest MTU to test.

Type: Int32
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 2
Default value: 1500
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -RemoteAddress
docs.text:
Specifies the name or IP of one or more remote computers.

Type: String[]
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases: Host, Name, Computer, ComputerName, TestAddress

Required: False
Position: 1
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Test network file transfer speeds, upload and download.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Test-NetworkSpeed [[-LocalPath] <String>] [[-RemotePath] <String>] [[-FileSize] <Int64>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Will test the file transfer speed of a generated file and provide you with the speed in Mbps (Megabit) and MBps (Megabyte) for uploads and downloads to a SMB file share.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Test-NetworkSpeed

Example of how to use this cmdlet using the configured values in the WSTools config.ps1 file.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Test-NetworkSpeed -FileSize 500KB

Another example of how to use this cmdlet but with the FileSize parameter. This example will generate 500 Kilobyte files to transfer.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 3
docs.text:
Test-NetworkSpeed -FileSize 100MB

Another example of how to use this cmdlet but with the FileSize parameter. This example will generate 100 Megabyte files to transfer.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 4
docs.text:
Test-NetworkSpeed -FileSize 1GB

Another example of how to use this cmdlet but with the FileSize parameter. This example will generate 1 Gigabyte files to transfer.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 5
docs.text:
Test-NetworkSpeed -LocalPath C:\Transfer

Another example of how to use this cmdlet but with the local path parameter.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 6
docs.text:
Test-NetworkSpeed -LocalPath D:\Temp -RemotePath \\server1.wstools.dev\Transfer

Another example of how to use this cmdlet but with the local and remote path parameters.

docs.title: -FileSize
docs.text:
Specifies the file size of the file to be generated and transferred. Enter in the format xxKB, xxMB, or xxGB.

Type: Int64
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 3
Default value: 0
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -LocalPath
docs.text:
Specifies the path to the local folder where a file will be generated and where a file will be copied to.

Type: String
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 1
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -RemotePath
docs.text:
Specifies the path to the remote folder where a file will be generated and where a file will be copied to.

Type: String
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 2
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Finds the response time of a remote computer.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Test-ResponseTime [[-RemoteAddress] <String[]>] [[-ThrottleLimit] <Int32>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Will find average, minimum, and maximum response times (from four pings) of a remote computer, which defaults to the computers logon server if an address is not specified.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Test-ResponseTime

Example of how to use this cmdlet.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Test-ResponseTime www.wanderingstag.com

Shows how to test the response time to the website www.wanderingstag.com.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 3
docs.text:
Test-ResponseTime COMP1,www.wanderingstag.com

Shows how to test the response time to the computer COMP1 and the website www.wanderingstag.com.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 4
docs.text:
Test-MTU COMP1,COMP2,COMP3,www.wanderingstag.com -ThrottleLimit 2

Shows how to test the response times to multiple computers, the test will be performed against two of the computers at a time.

docs.title: -RemoteAddress
docs.text:
Specifies the name of one or more remote computers.

Type: String[]
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases: Host, Name, Computer, ComputerName, TestAddress

Required: False
Position: 1
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -ThrottleLimit
docs.text:
Allows you to specify the most remote computers that will be tested at a time, defaults to 5.

Type: Int32
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 2
Default value: 5
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: Finds and fixes users with broken inheritance.

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Update-BrokenInheritance [[-SearchBase] <String>] [[-Identity] <String>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: Will search Active Directory for users that do not have permissions inheritance enabled and then fix the inheritance.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Update-BrokenInheritance -Identity "CN=Joe Snuffy,CN=Users,DC=wstools,DC=dev"

Will fix the broken inheritance on the user Joe Snuffy.

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Update-BrokenInheritance -SearchBase "CN=Users,DC=wstools,DC=dev"

Will fix the broken inheritance on all users in the Users OU.

docs.title: -Identity
docs.text:
Specify a user to fix the inheritance on. Can use sAMAccountName or distinguishedName. If no user is specified it will find all users with broken inheritance.

Type: String
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 2
Default value: None
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False

docs.title: -SearchBase
docs.text:
Specify the OU to search using the distinguishedName of the OU. If not specified it searches the whole domain.

Type: String
Parameter Sets: (All)
Aliases:

Required: False
Position: 1
Default value: (Get-ADDomain).DistinguishedName
Accept pipeline input: False
Accept wildcard characters: False
